title: The Greek Crisis Explained in Under 3 Minutes

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with Europe's idea of having a whole bunch of countries use the same currency?

options.label: A
options.text: It's too expensive for countries with low unemployment rates.

options.label: B
options.text: It's too cheap for countries with high unemployment rates.

options.label: C
options.text: It's hard to accommodate countries with different economic needs and varying levels of economic strength.

options.label: D
options.text: It's too complicated for small countries.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a country's currency when unemployment is high?

options.label: C
options.text: A country makes its currency cheaper by printing extra money, which can attract foreign investors and tourists.

options.label: D
options.text: A country typically tries to reduce unemployment by other means, rather than printing more money.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the price of Euros too low for Germany, but suitable for Greece?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Germany has a high unemployment rate and Greece has a low unemployment rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Germany has a low unemployment rate and Greece has a high unemployment rate.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Germany is a poor country and Greece is a rich country.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Germany has a strong economy and Greece has a weak economy.

multiple-choice.question: What is a major reason why the euro was created?

options.label: B
options.text: To promote peace on the continent and create a sense of unity among European countries.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase trade between European countries.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Greece's economy after it joined the euro in 2001?

options.label: A
options.text: It became stronger because everyone was willing to lend them money.

options.label: B
options.text: It became weaker because its economy was still weaker than some of the other European countries.

options.label: D
options.text: It was initially stronger, but its economy still has issues.

multiple-choice.question: What would be needed for the euro to really work for all European countries?

options.label: A
options.text: A closer union with more financial transfers between countries, and a system to support poorer countries.

options.label: B
options.text: A single government for all European countries.

options.label: C
options.text: A stronger economy for all European countries.

options.label: D
options.text: A single currency for all European countries.

multiple-choice.question: How do the poor states in the United States get money from the richer states?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the welfare system, Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.

options.label: B
options.text: Through taxes on the richer states.

options.label: C
options.text: Through investments in the richer states.

options.label: D
options.text: Through loans from the richer states.

multiple-choice.question: Why do Germans support poor German people but not poor Greek people?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they don't feel a sense of unity with Greece.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they don't think it's their responsibility to support other countries.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they don't think Greece's economy is strong enough.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they don't think Greece's culture is similar to theirs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the euro is not working for Greece?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Greece's economy is too weak, and the euro doesn't take into account the country's economic needs.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Greece's economy is too strong.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Greece is a small country.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Greece is a rich country.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall problem with the euro as a single currency for all European countries?

options.label: C
options.text: It doesn't take into account the different economic needs of each country, and there's a lack of financial support for poorer countries.

multiple-choice.question: What is the foundation for every movement your body makes?

options.text: Three curves: one at your neck, one at your shoulders, and one at the small of your back

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A straight line from your shoulders to your knee

options.label: C
options.text: A straight line from a point just in front of your shoulders, to behind your hip, to the front of your knee, to a few inches in front of your ankle

options.label: B
